Analyzing the claim and reasons provided, I agree that "Amazon will not necessarily kill off publishers." 

While it is true that Amazon has a considerable market share in the industry, it is not the only reading platform available. There are other digital platforms like Apple's iBooks, Barnes & Noble's Nook, and Kobo that are keeping competitiveness alive. Additionally, the increasing popularity of audiobooks has expanded opportunities for other platforms, such as Audible and iTunes. 

Furthermore, the persistence of a demand for physical books is a reality that delays the possible extinction of traditional publishing. According to a Pew Research study in 2019, 65% of Americans stated that they had read a print book in the past year, compared to only 25% who had read an e-book. 

Also, the services provided by traditional publishers cannot be neglected. Publishers offer industry expertise and auxiliary services for authors such as editing, designing, marketing, and distribution, which can significantly contribute to the success of a book. While Amazon offers self-publishing options, not all authors have the skillset or resources to independently manage these auxiliary tasks, reinforcing the role and importance of traditional publishers.

Thus, based on these facts and reasoning, the proposition that Amazon will not necessarily kill off publishers appears to be a valid one.
